### Course Objectives

Performance is not limited to those forms traditionally marked as being “artistic,” and that any theory of performance must, accordingly, be generalisable to a wide range of performative practices, across and between cultures, history, and conventional social categories….This means that scholars and students in Performance Studies need to develop new tools with which to develop a sense of the object of their analysis: not a text, but the living, breathing (and often ephemeral) performance itself….                                      

\--Ian Maxwell

This introductory course of “**Performance Studies & Critical Theories**” provides a lively and accessible overview of certain aspects of performance for beginning graduate students in performance studies, theatre studies, and literary and cultural studies. There was a “theory explosion” at the time performance studies was emerging as a major field of studies. As of today, critical theory has changed and transformed the field by enlarging the very conceptions of performance, returning performance history and criticism to philosophy, and overhauling the traditional delineations between texts and performances. These changes have had long-term consequences for how we think and write and perform. In addition, much of the critical theory of the past decades has been absorbed into scholarship in such a way that it is taken for granted in its conceptual vocabulary and in the context of performances. Critical theory has provided fresh starting points each time someone begins a research project or rethinks familiar terrain. This course is intended to provide a guided close reading of some major texts with regard to performance studies. In the course of this class, students will become familiar with a broad range of conceptual perspectives and scholarly applications of performance studies through reading, writing, and class presentations (performances).

Most important of all, the main goal of the course is not only to introduce the core theories and practices which in some way characterize the field of performance studies but also to stimulate students’ interests to further study related fields and help those who have already involved in performance studies to advance their knowledge about ritual theatre, theatre anthropology, and global and intercultural performance.

**Course Requirements and Evaluations**

1.  Thoughtful, active, and responsible participation and citizenship, including oral

discussion, preparation for class.

1.  Multiple 20-minute in-class PowerPoint oral reports, giving background to the materials being discussed. Please present leading themes of the materials according to the summary-response-position format as a way to define the context and the issues of the reading materials: 

a. Title and Basic Arguments

b. Methodologies

c. Main Points and key terms of the materials

d. Critiques

e. Works Consulted

3.  To enhance class-discussion registered students are required to keep a one-page

single-spaced journal per class meeting (from Week 2 to 15), in which they record their response (before and after the meeting) to the reading materials pre-assigned for each session.

1.  An 8-10 page double-spaced term paper, edited and polished, will be due on Jan.

7, 2022. 

1.  The term paper should be a thoughtful critical discussion of a topic or an issue related to the course.
2.  Hand in a prospectus on Dec. 17, 2021: A one-page proposal and a detailed

one-page outline of the project. 

5.  All papers must be typed, single- or double-spaced 12pt Times New Roman. On

the top left corner of the first page please include

a. Chinese name

b. Student ID number

c. The meeting date

d. A specific topic

6.  Papers should be turned in in due time. No late papers are allowed.

7.  Paper grades will be determined by content and mechanics.

a. Content (50 %): main ideas, argument, supporting evidence, diction,

development, etc.

b. Mechanics (50 %): grammar, spelling, punctuation, format, etc.

8.  Plagiarism is the ground for failure in this course. It will not be tolerated.

9.  Evaluations (100%):

a. Multiple PowerPoint oral reports (33 %): The grading will give considerable

weight to clarity of organization and to the quality of the oral delivery.

b. A journal collection (12 pages: one page per meeting (single-spaced) X 12

meetings) (33 %)

c. One research term paper (8-10 pages: double-spaced & “Works Cited”

included) (34 %)

10.  Attendance is a very important part of the requirement—in excess of 3 absences

is the ground for failure.
